conclusion: To determine when the particle is farthest from the starting point, analyze the given acceleration-time graph.
The graph shows acceleration versus time with key points at 0, t0/2, t0, 3t0/2, and 2t0.
Acceleration increases linearly from 0 to t0/2, decreases to 0 from t0/2 to t0, becomes negative from t0 to 3t0/2, and increases back to 0 from 3t0/2 to 2t0.
Velocity is the integral of acceleration with respect to time.
Determine when the velocity is maximum to find when the particle is farthest from the start.
Velocity will be maximum when the net area under the acceleration-time graph is greatest.
The graph is symmetric in acceleration.
Velocity peaks when the net area under the curve is at its maximum.
At t = t0, the acceleration returns to zero after reaching a0 and -a0.
The velocity at t = t0 is the integral of the acceleration from 0 to t0, which is maximum before the acceleration becomes negative.
The particle is farthest from the starting point at t = t0, where the velocity is at its maximum.
